comments.body: Minor editorial: separate sentences by semi-colon or comma (instead of full-stop), and add "and" after acknowledgement.

The rationale for the above funding levels is that unrestricted financial

comments.body: I would not agree with that as stated.  It could be read to imply that in-kind contributions are the least valuable.  But in-kind contributions can be extremely valuable, since the team does not have to deal with management, finances, etc.  I suspect you may have meant that in-kind contributions are easier to obtain, which is true.

I think with in-kind contributions you and I have slightly different things in mind. I'm really thinking about "company X decides to let one of their engineers contribute to NumPy". That likely means:

- the engineer works on things most important to company X
- there's extra maintainer effort required for guidance and code review

I suspect you are mostly thinking about maintainers being paid. But that falls under Institutional Partners, which is a different thing. Time for a maintainer is inherently more valuable than time of a new/external contributor.

Yes, so I think that really is the only part of the NEP that I think could benefit from some clarity---exactly how these relationships work: companies that contribute something they want to NumPy (costs us mentorship) vs. companies that allow maintainers to work on NumPy as part of their jobs (then we count them only if they give more than 6 months, if I recall correctly), vs groups that hire someone specifically to work on NumPy.
I can make that explicit, I agree that would help.

comments.body: Should this definition not go earlier where the amounts are defined?  That was why I reached for "in-kind" contribution there, because I didn't see a fit for this category.
connected to the Institutional Partners / Sponsors split, let's discuss on another comment.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +98,102 @@levels:

- 6 person-months/yr of paid work time for one or more NumPy maintainers or
  regular contributors to any NumPy team or activity

comments.body: Why not unify these two categories?

> Why not unify these two categories?

From the community building perspective, I quite like the concept of institutional partnerships. It might be just a matter of semantics in some cases, but psychologically I’d imagine, maybe naively, that orgs and ICs will have a greater sense of belonging and ownership if we assign them as partners instead of sponsors. Using the Jupyter Lab metaphor, it’s a difference between fostering a puppy from an ASPCA shelter vs simply donating money to them.
Let me comment on this on the PR rather than inline, it's important.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +101,105 @@  regular contributors to any NumPy team or activity

Institutional Partners get the same benefits as Sponsors, in addition to what
is specified in the NumPy governance document.
